subSubSection.paragraph:
non
Turritella bicarinata
m. (non Eichw.) — Pusch, 1837: 104, pl. 10, figs 3a–b [=
Archimediella indigena ( Eichwald, 1830 )
]. non
Turritella ( Archimediella ) bicarinata Eichw.
— Cossmann, 1912: 121 , pl. 6, figs 29–30 [=
Archimediella
].

Type material. Edouard Eichwald’s collection (not examined) is stored in the Museum of Paleontology and Stratigraphy at the Faculty of Geology of Saint Petersburg State University, Russia . Eichwald (1830) based his description on numerous syntypes from the Ukrainian localities Szuszkowce (Shushkivtsi), Bilka (Biłka), Zaleśce (Salisze), Poczajów Stary (Staryi Pochaiev), Tarnoruda (Tarnoruda) and Sawadynce.

Illustrated material. Fig. 7H : NHMW 2018/0272/0008, Gainfarn ( Austria ); Figs 16A
1 –A
2
: NHMW 1851/0002/0061, SL: 60.0 mm, MD: 16.4 mm , Grund ( Austria ), illustrated in Hörnes 1855, pl. 43, fig. 9; Figs 16B
1 –B
2
: NHMW 1846/0037/0378, SL: 51.5 mm , MD: 13.8 mm , Mikulov, ( Czech Republic ), illustrated in Hörnes 1855, pl. 43, fig. 11; Figs 16C
1 –C
2
: NHMW 1963/0513/0000, SL: 43.4 mm , MD: 13.4 mm , Steinebrunn ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber 1960 , pl. 2, fig. 26; Fig. 16D : NHMW 1860/0001/0275a, SL: 50.2 mm , MD: 14.8 mm , Steinebrunn ( Austria ); Figs 16E
1 –E
: NHMW 2018/0193/0001, SL: 38.2 mm , MD: 11.2 mm , Bilosirka, Ternopil Oblast , Ukraine .

Description. This species was described in detail by
Landau et al . (2013)
.

Shell measurements and ratios. (n=15): SL = 52.5 mm (σ = 4.2°), MD = 15.4 mm (σ = 1.5°). AA: 25.0° (σ = 3.4°), PA: 14.6° (σ = 1.0°). Lateral sinus (n = 7): LS angle = 16.7° (σ = 3.9°), LS p = 0.8 (σ = 0.06), LS d = 5.1 (σ = 0.80).

Discussion . This species was discussed in detail by
Landau et al. (2013)
; in addition, we observe up to eight inner lirae on the palatal wall and several weak basal lirae on most specimens. The lateral sinus of this species was described and illustrated by Marwick (1957) , as ‘shallow, oblique’. This is contrasted by our data, which reveal a moderately deep lateral sinus with weak inflection point below the adapical suture and a much more pronounced inflection point at the d spiral cord, with prosocyrt part, which passes into a shallowly sigmoidal basal sinus. It is possible that Marwick (1957) only had subadult or poorly preserved specimens at hand.

This is the most variable turritellid species in the Paratethyan record. Especially the strength and width of B and d spiral cords, the presence or absence of spiral sculpture on the sutural ramp and the overall profile (slender or stocky) display a striking variability. The morphologic plasticity is expressed by a multitude of variation and subspecies names. The most conspicuous morphotype is the screw-like
scalaria
-morph, which is characterized by strongly detached (but not fully uncoiled) teleoconch whorls, with deeply incised sutural ramp resulting in a very deeply incised suture. Its B and D spiral cords are extraordinarily raised and united in a flat sided or weakly concave spiral band. Friedberg (1935) discussed transitional morphs and own material (NHMW) documents that
bicarinata
and
scalaria
- morphs may co-occur at the same localities with transitional morphs (partly corresponding to
Turritella praescalaria Sieber, 1960
). Friedberg (1935) considered
Turritella scalaria
to be a late Badenian descendant of
T. bicarinata
, which developed in the Carpathian Foreland Basin after the Badenian Salinity Crisis (~13.8 Ma,
de Leeuw et al . 2010
). This view is incorrect, as the
scalaria
-morph appears in the Vienna Basin in deposits predating the Badenian Salinity Crisis (e.g. Gainfarn, Steinebrunn). Nevertheless, we are not aware of any early Miocene and early Badenian
scalaria
-morphs and the first specimens are collected from middle Badenian (upper Langhian) deposits. Moreover, this morphotype seems to be restricted to the Paratethys and was not detected from the Proto-Mediterranean.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Turritella anceps Handmann, 1822
is a junior synonym of
O. bicarinata
. This taxon was introduced by Handmann (1822) with a Latin description and a short discussion on its relationship with other taxa. Therefore,
Turritella anceps Woods in Bosworth, 1922
is a junior homonym of
Turritella anceps Handmann, 1822
. The Paleogene specimens from Peru , illustrated by Woods in Bosworth (1922) as
T. anceps
are surely not turritellids and we refrain from proposing a replacement name without providing a systematic revision.
